finding: Acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are associated with significant declines in pulmonary function, increased mortality, and high healthcare costs.
Rapid-acting bronchodilators, such as albuterol, are effective in managing acute exacerbations of COPD.
Systemic corticosteroids, such as prednisone, can reduce the frequency and severity of COPD exacerbations and prevent hospitalization in patients with moderate-to-severe COPD.
Long-term antibiotic use, such as azithromycin, can reduce the frequency of COPD exacerbations in patients with a history of exacerbation in the previous year.

Prevention of COPD exacerbations should be a key component of COPD management, and recent guidelines emphasize strategies such as smoking cessation, vaccination against influenza and pneumococcal disease, and long-term antibiotic use in patients with a history of exacerbation in the previous year.
